revision.text:
The '''12th Light Infantry Division''' is a [[formation (military)|formation]] of the [[Iraqi Army]]. It was activated in the 1970s or 1980s, probably disbanded after 1991, but reformed in 2008. It was an armoured division during the 1991 [[Persian Gulf War]]. The U.S. [[1st Infantry Division (United States)|1st Infantry Division (Mechanized)]] , [[Task Force 1-41 Infantry]], and [[2nd Armored Cavalry Regiment]] played a key role in the destruction of the division, destroying no less than 80 combat vehicles.<ref>Westfall, p. 88</ref> Other elements of the division were destroyed by British forces at [[Battle of Norfolk|Objective Dorset]].<ref>Bourque P.337</ref> Circa 2009 it was located in [[Tikrit]].<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/iraq/nia-12id.htm 12th Division, Iraqi Army]. GlobalSecurity.org.</ref>
The 12th Division was planned to be established in July 2008 by doubling the 4th Division. Its home base was planned to be at [[Tikrit]] and take into account the province of [[Salah ad-Din Governorate]]. It was to be initially made up of three trained strategic infrastructure brigades and was to receive the 4th Brigade, 4th Division. A new 4th Brigade was to have been formed for the 4th Division from effective excess staff from the other three brigades of the division.
Division Units: * Headquarters and Service Company * 46th Motorised Brigade (''ex-1st Strategic Infrastructure Brigade'') * 47th Motorised Brigade (''ex-2nd Strategic Infrastructure Brigade'') * 48th Brigade (''ex-9th Strategic Infrastructure Brigade'') * 49th Brigade (''ex-4-4'') * 12th Motorized Transportation Regiment
The 49th Brigade, former 4th Brigade of the 4th Division, the more operational brigade of 12th Division is currently (July 2008) deployed to Baghdad to take part in the battles of [[Sadr City]].
The 48th Brigade is now part of the 4th Division.
As July 2010, division's units are : * Headquarters and Service Company * 15th (Eagles) AAslt Brigade (from 4th Division) * 46th Motorised Brigade (''ex-1st Strategic Infrastructure Brigade'') * 47th Motorised Brigade (''ex-2nd Strategic Infrastructure Brigade'') * 49th Brigade (''ex-4-4'') * 12th Motorized Transportation Regiment
==References== {{reflist}}
==Works Consulted== *{{Cite book|first=Stephen A.| last=Bourque |title= Jayhawk! The 7th Corps in the Persian Gulf War |publisher = Center of Military History, United States Army|date=2001|lccn = 2001028533|OCLC=51313637}} *http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/iraq/12ad.htm
[[Category:Divisions of Iraq]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 2008]]
{{mil-unit-stub}} {{iraq-mil-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Aleksandra and Konstantin | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Belarus]] | genre = | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = Aleksandra Kirsanova
Konstantin Drapezo | past_members = }} '''Aleksandra and Konstantin''' is a [[Belarus|Belarusian]] musical duo composed of singer '''Aleksandra Kirsanova''' and guitarist '''Konstantin Drapezo'''. They represented [[Belarus]] in their inaugural entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], singing "[[My Galileo]]" in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004 Contest]]. {{S-start}} {{Succession box | before=none | title=[[Belarus in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=2004 | after=[[Angelica Agurbash]]
with ''[[Love Me Tonight (Angelica Agurbash song)|Love me Tonight]]'' | }} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aleksandra And Konstantin}} [[Category:Belarusian Eurovision Song Contest entrants]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 2004]] [[Category:Belarusian pop music groups]] {{Belarus-stub}}

revision.text:
{{hatnote|"Bé d'interès cultural" or "BIC" may refer also in Catalan to Spanish [[Bien de Interés Cultural]]}} A '''Bé d'interès cultural''' (BIC) is the [[Andorra]]n name for a [[National Heritage Site]] listed by the Andorran heritage register, [[Patrimoni Cultural]].<ref>{{ca icon}} [http://www.bopa.ad/bopa.nsf/c56341fced070c89c12566c700571ddd/e2a748c3b17c5373c1256d6500265924?OpenDocument Law 9/2003, of June 12th, del patrimoni cultural d'Andorra], official bulletin of the government of Andorra.</ref>
The term literally means "Property of Cultural Interest", although a better translation could be "Heritage of Cultural Interest", as Andorra now protects not only material heritage, like monuments or movable works of art, but also [[intangible cultural heritage]].
== Sub-categories == *Non-movable Andorran heritage is divided into the following classifications: ** ''Monument'', which as the term [[monument]] implies, refers to buildings or other individual constructions such as public art or memorials that have significant cultural value. ** ''Conjunt arquitectònic'' (architectural group or set), grouping of buildings that constitutes a coherent unit, regardless of individual value. ** ''Paisatge cultural'' (cultural landscape), joint work of man and nature with aesthetic, historical or cultural value. E.g. [[Madriu-Perafita-Claror Valley]] ** ''Zona arqueològica'' (archaeological area), area with traces of human intervention in the past. ** ''Zona paleontològica'' (paleontological area), area with fossilized remains forming a coherent unit. *Movable heritage, such archaeological objects, bibliographic heritage, and large works of art.
==See also== *[[Cultural Heritage of Andorra]] * [[Culture of Andorra]] * [[Cultural Heritage]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Be D'interes Cultural}} [[Category:Heritage registers in Andorra]] [[Category:Andorran culture]] [[Category:Andorran law]]
{{Andorra-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5beta)
revision.text:
The '''Club of Vienna''' is an international association which has 24 members<ref>[http://www.clubofvienna.org/website/output.php?id=1974&language=1 Club of Vienna] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719230159/http://www.clubofvienna.org/website/output.php?id=1974&language=1 |date=2011-07-19 }}, retrieved online: 2009-05-23</ref> and interested in social, scientific, economic and ecological issues.
== Areas of Focus == Particular attention is given to:<ref>[http://www.clubofvienna.org/website/output.php?id=1493&language=2 Club of Vienna] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904015539/http://www.clubofvienna.org/website/output.php?id=1493&language=2 |date=2009-09-04 }}, retrieved online: 2009-05-23</ref>
* intellectual, cultural, ecological and economic potential in the area of conflict between regional and national interests * the trend towards [[globalization]] * possible scenarios for the city of [[Vienna]].
== Founding president == *[[Rupert Riedl]] (1925-2005)
== Current topics of the Club of Vienna ==
*Consequences of migration in Europe: opening of the east, transit, currents of traffic, economic consequences, [[social issues]], culture; advantages and disadvantages *Participatory decision-making in democracy *[[Acceleration phenomena]] *Non-material indicators of prosperity *The new [[capitalism]] *Europe in the 21st century – two differing speeds? *Slaves and masters in information society *[[Sustainability]] as an investment principle *Examine "[[The Reasons of Growth]]"
== Literature ==
* ''Kapitalismus gezähmt? Weltreligionen und Kapitalismus'' (H. Knoflacher, K. Woltron, A. Rosik-Kölbl, editors), 2006. Verlag echo media, Vienna * ''Wege in den Postkapitalismus'' (K. Woltron, H. Knoflacher, A. Rosik-Kölbl, editors), 2004. Verlag edition selene, Vienna * ''Die Ursachen des Wachstums. Unsere Chancen zur Umkehr'' (R. Riedl, M. Delpos, editors), 1996. Verlag Kremayr und Scheriau: Vienna
==See also== * [[Peak Oil]] * [[Club of Rome]] * [[Club of Budapest]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.clubofvienna.org Official home page]
[[Category:Futurology]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks based in Europe]] [[Category:Think tanks based in Austria]] [[Category:Globalism]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Distillerie Dillon | logo = File:Distillerie Dillon.JPG |logo_caption = The Distillerie Dillon | type = | industry = [[Rum]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = Rhum Dillon | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = [http://www.rhums-dillon.com/ Official website] }}
The '''Distillerie Dillon''' is in [[Fort de France]] in [[Martinique]]. It distills many types of [[rum]] from the locally grown [[sugar cane]]. It is powered by a [[Corliss steam engine]] that was built in 1922.<ref>[http://voyage.michelin.fr/web/destination/Martinique-Fort_de_France/site-Distillerie_Dillon-Rte_de_Chateauboeuf_9 Michelin guide] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413070637/http://voyage.michelin.fr/web/destination/Martinique-Fort_de_France/site-Distillerie_Dillon-Rte_de_Chateauboeuf_9 |date=April 13, 2013 }}</ref>
==History== The site of the distillery was settled by sugar farmers in 1690. The name stems from [[Arthur Dillon (1750-1794)]] a soldier with Lafayette's troops in the American War of Independence. Serving with [[Dillon's Regiment]], of the [[Irish Brigade (France)]], he had been created a colonel at the age of 16.<ref name=dillon>http://www.rhums-dillon.com/ Dillons Rum website</ref>
On returning to his home from the war, he married a rich widow, named Louise. Then they bought the estate, flourishing with sugar cane, and had a daughter Fanny.<ref name=dillon/> Dillon became a deputy, and his daughter was presented by her cousin Josephine to [[Napoleon]]. She married General Bertrand, and they both accompanied Napoleon into exile on [[Elba]] and [[St Helena]].<ref name=dillon/> On returning to the Dillon Plantation, she campaigned against slavery.
==Process== There are ten varieties of sugar cane used by Dillon. The cane is grown for two years and when harvested the sugar is extracted over a period of 2 to 3 days. Speed is essential. The saying goes "the cane should have its feet in the earth and its head in the mill" <ref name=dillon/> The cane is crushed three times to release the juice by a steam engine driven mill. Water is added and the juice is allowed to ferment- it is again milled to crush the sugar, and fermentation starts. The residue cane is used to fire the boilers that provide the steam. The distillation is a slow process, in columns heated to {{convert|65|C}}, producing an alcohol of 65%. It rests for five months then is reduced and bottled at 50% to 55%.<ref name=dillon/>
==See also==
* [[List of French rums]] * [[List of rum producers]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rhums-dillon.com/ Official website]
[[Category:Martinican culture]] [[Category:Economy of Martinique]] [[Category:Rums]] [[Category:Distilleries]] [[Category:Drink companies of France]]
{{Europe-company-stub}} {{Distilled-beverage-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Franz Schurmann | residence = | other_names = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Herbert Franz Schurmann | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|6|21|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[New York, New York|New York City]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2010|8|20|1926|6|21}} | death_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | death_cause = [[Parkinson's disease]], [[Alzheimer's disease]] | known = | occupation = Sociologist, historian, author | title = | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = Sandy Close | children = Mark Anderson Schurmann, Peter Leon Schurmann | relations = Dorothy Schurmann (sister) | website = | footnotes = | employer = [[Pacific News Service]] | height = | weight = }} '''Herbert Franz Schurmann''' (June 21, 1926 – August 20, 2010) was an American [[sociology|sociologist]] and [[history|historian]] who was best known for his research and writings about [[People's Republic of China|Communist China]] during the [[Cold War]] period. He taught at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], in the departments of Sociology and History for 38 years, and he also served a term as the head of the Center for Chinese Studies. He was an early opponent of the [[Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War|Vietnam War]], and was the first American professor to visit [[Hanoi]] during the bombing raids there. He co-founded the [[Pacific News Service]] in 1970 together with author [[Orville Schell]], serving as editor and commentator, and wrote the weekly "Predictions" column.<ref name=SFCObit>Egelko, Bob. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/08/22/BAGV1F1QA8.DTL "Historian and China expert Franz Schurmann dies"], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', August 23, 2010. Accessed August 27, 2010.</ref>
==Life and scholarly career== Schurmann was born on June 21, 1926, in [[Astoria, Queens]], New York, and grew up in [[Bloomfield, Connecticut]]. He developed fluency in as many as 12 languages, acquiring them from his [[Slovenia]]n father who spoke five languages himself, his mother who was an immigrant from [[Germany]], and from the dialects spoken in the [[melting pot]] community where he was raised. He briefly attended [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College]] in nearby [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. He was drafted by the [[United States Army]] during [[World War II]] and was assigned to learn [[Japanese language|Japanese]], serving as a newspaper censor during the American [[occupation of Japan]]. He befriended [[Stefan Brecht]] during his Army service and met [[Thomas Mann]] and other German émigrés at the California home of Stefan's father [[Bertolt Brecht]]. After completing his military service Schurmann was awarded a Ph.D. in [[Asian studies]] from [[Harvard University]], which he was able to attend using his [[G.I. Bill]] benefits as a veteran.<ref name=NYTObit>Weber, Bruce. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/27/us/27schurmann.html "Franz Schurmann, Cold War Expert on China, Dies at 84"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 26, 2010. Accessed August 27, 2010.</ref><ref name=NAMObit>Staff. [http://newamericamedia.org/2010/08/pns-co-founder-franz-schurmann-dies.php "PNS Co-founder Franz Schurmann Dies"], [[New America Media]], August 23, 2010. Accessed August 27, 2010.</ref>
During the late 1950s, Schurmann spent two years exploring [[Afghanistan]] on horseback, where he documented a blue-eyed, blond-haired tribe that descended from the invasions by [[Genghis Khan]], a history that he recounted in his 1962 book ''The Mongols of Afghanistan: An Ethnography of the Moghôls and Related Peoples of Afghanistan''.<ref name=NAMObit/> He was an early opponent of the Vietnam War, founding the Berkeley Faculty Peace Committee in 1965 and visiting [[North Vietnam]] with author and political activist [[Mary McCarthy (author)|Mary McCarthy]] in 1968. In 1967, Schurmann signed a letter declaring his intention to [[tax resistance|refuse to pay taxes]] in protest against the U.S. war against Vietnam, and urging other people to also take this stand.<ref>"An Open Letter" [http://collection1.libraries.psu.edu/cdm/singleitem/collection/transaction/id/17162 archived at Horowitz Transaction Publishers Archive]</ref>
His major work ''[[Ideology and Organization in Communist China]]'' was published in 1966, just as Mao's [[Cultural Revolution]] was starting, and was revised and enlarged in 1968 and 1971. A widely influential analysis, the book applied the sociological insights of [[Max Weber]] to interviews Schurmann conducted in [[Hong Kong]] with refugees and wide reading in Chinese newspapers and documents. The book demonstrates how [[Mao Zedong]]'s "dialectical conception of Chinese society" structured his organizational approach to the [[Chinese Communist Party]] and the government. The book argued that a "consistent yet changing ideology" created a web of organization which covered and penetrated all aspects of Chinese society, building from the 1930s.<ref>''Ideology and Organization in Communist China'' (Berkeley: [[University of California Press]], 1966; revised and enlarged, 1968, 1971</ref> He edited the three-volume series ''The China Reader'' with [[Orville Schell]], a student of his who became an author and China expert in his own right. Together with Schell, he established the Pacific News Service in 1970, with the goal of providing Americans with more detailed coverage of news from Asia and Latin America. The service created [[New America Media]] in 1996, a multimedia ethnic news agency and a coalition of ethnic media.<ref name=NYTObit/>
His 1974 work ''The Logic of World Power'' provided a summary of international relations following World War II. ''The Foreign Politics of [[Richard Nixon]]'', a book he wrote in the 1970s about the U.S. President's role in foreign affairs, was not published until 1987.
As he developed his thinking about global power and economy, he expanded his skills to keep abreast of world developments. Already fluent in French, German, Russian, Chinese, Japanese, and other languages, he now in his sixties learnt enough written Arabic to be able to read the [[Koran]] and the Arab-language press. This enabled him to write hundreds of columns for Pacific News, reporting on the development and goals of [[militant Islam]].<ref name=NAMObit/>
He died at age 84 on August 20, 2010, at his home in [[San Francisco]] due to complications of [[Alzheimer's disease]] and [[Parkinson's disease]]. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, journalist [[Sandy Close]], as well as by two sons, Peter and Mark Schurmann, his daughter-in-law Aruna Lee, and his grandson Leon.<ref name=NAMObit/>
==Publications== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *''The Politics of Escalation in Vietnam,'' with Peter Dale Scott and Reginald Zelnik. Fawcett, 1966. *''Ideology and Organization in Communist China'' *''The Logic of World Power: An Inquiry into the Origins, Currents, and Contradictions of World Politics''. Pantheon, 1974. *''Imperial China: The Decline of the Last Dynasty and the Origins of Modern China, the 18th and 19th Centuries''. 1967. (with [[Orville Schell]]). First in The China Reader series. *''Republican China: Nationalism, War, and the Rise of Communism, 1911-1949'' (with [[Orville Schell]]). Second in The China Reader series. *''Communist China: Revolutionary Reconstruction and International Confrontation, 1949 to the Present'' (with Orville Schell) (1968). Third in The China Reader series. *''The Foreign Politics of Richard Nixon: The Grand Design'', Institute of International Studies, University of California, Berkeley, 1987. *''American Soul'' (a personal narrative). 2001. {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Schurmann, Franz}} [[Category:Historians from New York (state)]] [[Category:American sociologists]] [[Category:American tax resisters]] [[Category:Mongolists]] [[Category:American foreign policy writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:News agency founders]] [[Category:American anti–Vietnam War activists]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Trinity College (Connecticut) alumni]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:Writers from San Francisco]] [[Category:People from Astoria, Queens]] [[Category:People from Bloomfield, Connecticut]] [[Category:Deaths from Parkinson's disease]] [[Category:Deaths from Alzheimer's disease]] [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Asian studies]] [[Category:Activists from California]]

revision.text:
The '''Greater Ranges''' comprise the high [[mountain range]]s of [[Asia]]: *the [[Himalayas]], *the [[Karakoram]], *the [[Hindu Kush]], *the [[Pamir Mountains]], *the [[Hengduan Mountains]], *the [[Tien Shan]], *the [[Kunlun Shan]], *the [[Transhimalaya]].
The [[UIAA]] gives a broader definition of the Greater Ranges than the traditional one. With the increasing popularity of global travel and adventure sports, this definition is now somewhat more popular than the original. In addition to the ranges listed above, the ranges also comprise: *the [[Seven Summits]] (Messner list) *the [[Andes]] of South America *the [[Alaska Range]] and the [[Saint Elias Mountains]] of North America *the [[Rwenzori Mountains]] and [[Mount Kenya]] of Africa
All of these ranges have peaks over {{Convert|4800|m|ft|sigfig=4}}, and most have peaks over {{Convert|6000|m|ft|sigfig=4}}. The Greater Ranges contain all of the world's peaks higher than {{Convert|7000|m|ft|sigfig=4}}.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140108090610/http://www.theuiaa.org/expeditions_general_regulations.html UIAA - Greater ranges and major geographical areas]</ref>
The term was popular amongst [[alpinist]]s in the Victorian period and was used to distinguished the high peaks of Asia from the European [[Alps]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Mountain ranges of Asia]] [[Category:Landforms of East Asia]] [[Category:Landforms of Central Asia]] [[Category:Landforms of South Asia]] [[Category:Mountains of Asia]] [[Category:Mountaineering]]
{{-}} {{Asia-geo-stub}} {{Climbing-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox Airline |airline = Itek Air |image = Itek Air logo.png |image_size = 250 |IATA = GI |ICAO = IKA |callsign = SMART ITEK |founded = 1999 |ceased = 2010 |hubs = [[Manas International Airport]] |secondary_hubs = |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |subsidiaries = |fleet_size = 2 |destinations = 4 |parent = |company_slogan = |headquarters = [[Bishkek]], [[Kyrgyzstan]] |key_people = |website = |aoc=|num_employees=}} [[File:Itek Air Boeing 737-200 Naumenko.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Itek Air Boeing 737-200, Moscow, 2008, [[Iran Aseman Airlines Flight 6895|which was crashed at 24 August, 2008]].]] '''Itek Air, Ltd''' ({{lang-ru|ООО Авиакомпания «ИТЕК-ЭЙР»}}) was an [[airline]] based in [[Bishkek]] ([[Manas International Airport]]) in [[Kyrgyzstan]].
==Destinations== As of October 2008, Itek Air operated scheduled passenger flights to the following destinations:<ref>{{Ru icon}} [[Polyot-Sirena]] [http://www.polets.ru/cgi-bin/sh.pl?Mode=AK&AKIndex=85&AKCode=85 Flight schedule]</ref><ref>{{Ru icon}} Itek Air website [http://www.itekair.kg/ru/moscow4 Расписание рейсов]</ref>
;[[China|People's Republic of China]] *[[Ürümqi]] ([[Diwopu International Airport]]) ;[[Kyrgyzstan]] *[[Bishkek]] ([[Manas International Airport]]) '''Hub''' *[[Osh]] ([[Osh Airport]]) ;[[Russia]] *[[Moscow]] ([[Domodedovo International Airport]]) *[[Novosibirsk]] ([[Tolmachevo Airport]])
The airline is [[List of air carriers banned in the European Union|banned]] from flying within the [[European Union]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/air-ban/pdf/list_en.pdf |title=LIST OF AIR CARRIERS OF WHICH ALL OPERATIONS ARE SUBJECT TO A BAN WITHIN THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY |accessdate=2008-08-25 |date=24 July 2008 |publisher=European Union Transport commission |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325010606/http://ec.europa.eu/transport/air-ban/pdf/list_en.pdf |archivedate=25 March 2009 |df= }}</ref>
==Accidents and inccidents== ===Iran Aseman Airlines Flight 6895=== {{main|Iran Aseman Airlines Flight 6895}} *On 24 August 2008, a [[Boeing 737-200]], owned and operated by Itek Air (a Kyrgyz company) on a charter flight for [[Iran Aseman Airlines]], flight 6895, crashed near [[Manas International Airport]] in [[Bishkek]], the capital city of [[Kyrgyzstan]], while attempting an emergency landing, returning to the airport of origin, 10 minutes after departure. Sixty-eight people were killed and 22 people survived the crash.<ref>{{Cite web|title=65 dead in Kyrgyz air crash|url=http://sify.com/news/fullstory.php?id=14745698|publisher=''[[Sify|sify.com]]''|accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref>
==Fleet== The fleet consisted of the following aircraft:<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=IKA&al_op=1 |title = Itek Air | accessdate = 2008-08-24 | publisher = ch-aviation.ch}}</ref>
*2 [[Boeing 737-200]] The registration of the aircraft were EX-127, EX-311 and EX-009. The last one crashed near Bishkek on 24 August 2008.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category|Itek Air}} *[http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=IKA&al_op=1 Itek Air Fleet]
{{Airlines of Kyrgyzstan}}
[[Category:Defunct airlines of Kyrgyzstan]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1999]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2010]]
{{Kyrgyzstan-transport-stub}} {{Asia-airline-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2014}}
'''Lejeloven''', formally ''Lov om leje'', is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[law]] which governs [[Leasehold estate|rentals]] of residential tenancies in private rented accommodation, including [[single-family home]]s, [[condominium]]s, so-called mixed properties and club premises. The law therefore does not apply to [[public housing]] or to commercial leases.
The law is intended to protect the tenant, by, among other provisions, limiting how much a [[landlord]] may ask in rent; in addition, the rent must be proportionate to the value of the premises. The law also states that a maximum of three months' rent may be required as a deposit, and that there is to be a separate accounting for heating, and finally the law sets out the rules which apply with respect to maintenance and expenditures incurred in connection with improvements.
The Act is subject to periodic review and was last revised on 1 July 2015.
Public rental housing is governed by the so-called ''M ordningen'', for ''miksordningen'' or ''mellemtingsordningen'' (mixed or temporary system).
== External links == *[https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/r0710.aspx?id=132875 Lejeloven on retsinformation.dk]
[[Category:Danish law]]
{{Denmark-stub}}

page.title: Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein

revision.text:
{{infobox military award | name = Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein
''Fürstlich liechtensteinischer Verdienstorden'' | image = Fürstliche Liechtensteinische Verdienstorden Ritterkreuz.gif | image_size = 120px | caption = Cross of the Order | awarded_by = [[Serene Highness|HSH]] [[List of monarchs of Liechtenstein|The Sovereign Prince of Liechtenstein]] | country = {{LIE}} | type = [[Chivalric order|Order]] | eligibility = | for = outstanding service to the Principality of Liechtenstein | campaign = | status = | description = | motto = | clasps = | post-nominals = | established = 22 July 1937 | first_award = | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = | same = | lower = | related = | image2 = [[File:Order of Merit (Liechtenstein) Ribbon.Bar.gif|90px]] | caption2 = Ribbon of the order }} The '''Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein''' ({{lang-de|Fürstlich liechtensteinischer Verdienstorden}}) is an [[order of merit]] of the Principality of [[Liechtenstein]] that is awarded for services rendered to the [[principality]]. [[Franz I, Prince of Liechtenstein|Prince Franz I]] founded the Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein on 22 July 1937 (on the anniversary of his marriage).{{cite web |url=http://www.medals.org.uk/liechtenstein/liechtenstein001.htm |title=Principality of Liechtenstein: Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein |author=Megan C. Robertson |date=9 August 2008 |work=Medals of the World |publisher= |accessdate=26 April 2011}} ==Grades of the Order== There order is presented in six grades. There is also an associated gold and silver medal of merit.{{cite web|url=http://www.fuerstenhaus.li/en/fuerstenhaus/titel_orden/|title=Titles, Orders, Decorations|author=|date=|work=The Princely House of Liechtenstein|publisher=|accessdate=26 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610075359/http://www.fuerstenhaus.li/en/fuerstenhaus/titel_orden/|archivedate=10 June 2011|df=}} * Grand Star of the Princely Liechtenstein Order of Merit. * Grand Cross With Diamonds of the Princely Liechtenstein Order of Merit. * Grand Cross of the Princely Liechtenstein Order of Merit. * Commander's Cross with Star of the Princely Liechtenstein Order of Merit. * Commander's Cross of the Princely Liechtenstein Order of Merit. * Knight's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein. * Gold Medal of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein. * Silver Medal of Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein. == Recipients == Recipients have included: * [[Hans-Adam II, Prince of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Alois, Hereditary Prince of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Franz I, Prince of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Franz Joseph II, Prince of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Marie, Princess of Liechtenstein|Princess Marie of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Alois Mock]] - Grand Cross * [[Prince Nikolaus of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Wolfgang Schüssel]] - Grand Cross * [[Alexander Van der Bellen]] - Grand Star * [[Sophie, Hereditary Princess of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Countess Georgina von Wilczek|Princess Georgina of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star * [[Princess Margaretha of Liechtenstein]] - Grand Star ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://semon.fr/DECORATIONS_LIECHTENSTEIN.htm DÉCORATIONS du LIECHTENSTEIN] (French), décorations in colour, including the [http://semon.fr/merite_lichtenstein_plaque.jpg plaque]. *[https://www.gesetze.li/konso/1937012000 Concerning the foundation of the Order of Merit and its medal] (German) - gesetze.li [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Orders of knighthood awarded to heads of state, consorts and sovereign family members|Merit of the Principality of Liechtenstein, Order of the]] {{Liechtenstein-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Archdiocese | name = Ozamiz | latin = Archidioecesis Ozamisanus | local = Arkidiyosesis ng Ozamiz | image = <!-- Or specify coat of arms below --> | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | coat = <!-- Coat of arms file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | coat_size = | coat_alt = | flag = <!-- Flag file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | flag_size = | flag_alt = <!---- Locations ----> | country = [[Philippines]] | territory = | province = Ozamiz | metropolitan = | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = <!-- Use {{coord}} --> <!---- Statistics ----> | area_km2 = 1,939 | area_sqmi = <!-- Area in square miles, automatically converted --> | area_footnotes = | population = 628,000 | population_as_of = 2013 | catholics = 485,000 | catholics_percent = 77.2 | parishes = <!-- Number of parishes in the diocese --> | churches = <!-- Number of churches in the diocese --> | congregations = <!-- Number of congregations in the diocese --> | schools = <!-- Number of church supported schools in the diocese --> | members = <!-- Number of members in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | sui_iuris_church = [[Latin Church]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = | cathedral = Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in [[Ozamiz]] | cocathedral = | patron = <!-- Patron saint(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | patron_title = <!-- Use to override the default label "Patron saint" --> | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} <!-- DO NOT CHANGE. This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = <!-- Name and title of the current ordinary of the diocese --> | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = [[Martin Jumoad]] | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = [[Jesus Dosado]] <!---- Map ----> | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = [http://ozamizarchdiocese.org/ Website of the Archdiocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ozamiz''' is an archdiocese of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] in the [[Provinces of the Philippines|province]] of [[Misamis Occidental]], southern [[Philippines]]. The archdiocese cathedral is the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in [[Ozamiz City]], and its present archbishop is Martin Jumoad.<ref name=chdozam>{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dozam.html |title=Archdiocese of Ozamiz |date=23 April 2017 |website=Catholic Hierarchy |last=Cheney |first=David M. |accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref>
The larger [[ecclesiastical province]] over which the archbishop of Ozamiz serves as metropolitan see covers the northwestern portion of the island of [[Mindanao]], including the [[highly urbanized city]] of [[Iligan]] and the provinces of [[Misamis Occidental]], [[Lanao del Norte]], [[Lanao del Sur]], [[Zamboanga del Norte]] and [[Zamboanga del Sur]].<ref name=chdozam/>
==History== The Territorial Prelature of Ozamiz was erected on 27 January 1951 from the territory of the then-[[Archdiocese of Cagayan de Oro|diocese of Cagayan de Oro]].<ref name=cbcp/> This prelature covered the provinces of [[Lanao (province)|Lanao]] (which were split in 1952 into [[Lanao del Norte]] and [[Lanao del Sur]]) and [[Misamis Occidental]], and the chartered cities of [[Iligan]], [[Marawi]], [[Oroquieta]] (established 1969), [[Ozamiz]] and [[Tangub]] (established 1967).<ref name=chdozam/>
On 17 February 1971 [[Pope Paul VI]] elevated the Prelature of Ozamiz into a diocese, covering only parishes within [[Misamis Occidental]], with [[Jesus Varela]] appointed as its [[bishop]].<ref name=chdozam/> The new diocese became a suffragan of the [[Archdiocese of Zamboanga]].<ref name=cbcp>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbcponline.org/jurisdictions/ozamiz.html |website=Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines |accessdate=26 May 2017 |title=Archdiocese of Ozamiz}}</ref>
On 24 January 1983, Ozamiz was elevated to an archdiocese, with the dioceses of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Dipolog|Dipolog]] (established 1967), [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Iligan|Iligan]] (established 1971) and [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Pagadian|Pagadian]] (established 1971), and the [[Territorial Prelature of Marawi|Prelature of Marawi]] (established 1976) as its suffragan dioceses.<ref name=chdozam/> [[Jesus Dosado]] was officially installed as its first archbishop on 10 April 1983.<ref name=cbcp/>
==Suffragan dioceses== *[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Dipolog|Diocese of Dipolog]] *[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Iligan|Diocese of Iligan]] *[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Pagadian|Diocese of Pagadian]]
===Prelature=== *[[Territorial Prelature of Marawi|Prelature of Marawi]]
==Bishops==
===Ordinaries===
====Prelates of Ozamiz==== # [[Patrick Cronin (bishop)|Patrick Cronin]], [[Missionary Society of St. Columban|S.S.C.M.E.]] (24 May 1955–13 October 1970)<ref name=chdozam/>
====Bishops of Ozamiz==== # [[Jesus Varela]] (17 February 1971–27 November 1980)<ref name=chdozam/> # [[Jesus Dosado]], C.M. (29 July 1981–24 January 1983)<ref name=chdozam/>
====Archbishops of Ozamiz==== # [[Jesus Dosado]], C.M. (24 January 1983–4 October 2016)<ref name=chdozam/> # [[Martin Jumoad]] (4 October 2016–present)<ref name=chdozam/>
==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in the Philippines]]
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dozam.html Catholic Hierarchy] *[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/ozam0.htm GCatholic] *[http://www.cbcponline.org/jurisdictions/ozamiz.html CBCP]

{{italic title}} [[File:WSJAsia logo.svg|thumb|The logo of ''The Wall Street Journal Asia'']]
'''''The Wall Street Journal Asia''''', a version of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', provides news and analysis of global business developments for an [[Asia]]n audience. Formerly known as ''The Asian Wall Street Journal'', it was founded in 1976 and is printed in nine Asian cities: [[Bangkok]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Jakarta]], [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Manila]], [[Seoul]], [[Singapore]], [[Taipei]], and [[Tokyo]]. Average circulation for 2011 was 83,421. Its largest markets in order of importance are: Hong Kong, Singapore, the [[Philippines]], [[Japan]], [[Thailand]], [[South Korea]], Indonesia, Taiwan, Malaysia, China, India, and Vietnam.
The paper's main regional office is in [[Hong Kong]], and its former editor, international, was [[Daniel Hertzberg]].
The first editor and publisher of the ''Asian Journal'' was [[Peter R. Kann]], the former chairman and chief executive officer of [[Dow Jones & Company]].
''The Wall Street Journal Asia'' can also be found at The Wall Street Journal Online at WSJ.com, the largest paid subscription news site on the Web. ''The Wall Street Journal Asia ''is also published online in Chinese at Chinese.wsj.com.
The final print edition of the newspaper was published on 9 October 2017.
==Statistics==
*Its readers are 77.9% Asian citizens, and 67.4% work in top management. *Its readership has an average annual income of US$229,000 and an average annual household income of US$301,000.
== See also == * ''[[The Wall Street Journal Europe]]'' * [[:Category:Lists of newspapers by country]]
==External links== *[http://www.wsj-asia.com ''The Wall Street Journal Asia''] * {{Newseum front page|WSJA}} *[http://www.chinese.wsj.com Chinese.wsj.com]
{{Dow Jones}}

revision.comment: Included information regarding disruptions caused by decommissioning the satellite
revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-66 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1990-103A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1990-103A|title=Navstar 2A-01|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 20959 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIA]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1816|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|26 November 1990, 21:39:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II|Delta II 7925-9.5]],}} D201 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = 25 January 2016 | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20072|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20293|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 717.98 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-66''', also known as '''GPS IIA-1''', '''GPS II-10''' and '''GPS SVN-23''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which formed part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the first of nineteen [[GPS Block IIA|Block IIA]] GPS satellites to be launched, and was the oldest GPS satellite still in operation until its decommissioning on 25 January 2016. USA-66 was launched at 21:39:01 UTC on 26 November 1990, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D201, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-66 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star 37|Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2a.htm|title=GPS-2A (Navstar-2A)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 30 December 1990, USA-66 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20072|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20293|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.98 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It was initially given PRN 23, which it used until its retirement in February 2004; however, it was subsequently reactivated broadcasting PRN 32 and in February 2008 it rejoined the operational constellation. It is located in slot 5 of plane E of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite has a mass of {{convert|1816|kg}}. It had a design life of 7.5 years, but remained in service for over 25 years. On 25 January 2016, USA-66 was decommissioned, and removed from the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/?Do=gpsShowNanu&num=2016008|title=Notice Advisory To NAVSTAR Users (NANU) 2016008|publisher=U.S. Coast Guard Navigation Center|accessdate=26 January 2016}} When engineers took it offline, its disappearance triggered a software bug that left the timing of 15 of the remaining GPS satellites off by 13.7 microseconds, causing widespread GPS disruptions. {{cite web|url=https://tf.nist.gov/general/pdf/2886.pdf|title=The effects of the January 2016 UTC offset anomaly on GPS-controlled clocks monitored at NIST|accessdate=2 March 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1990}} [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1990]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

page.title: United Nations Angola Verification Mission I

revision.text:
The '''United Nations Angola Verification Mission I''' ('''I UNAVEM''')<ref>[https://www.un.org/Depts/DPKO/Missions/unavem1/unavemi.htm United Nations Angola Verification Mission I]</ref> was a [[peacekeeping]] mission that existed from January 1989 to June 1991 in [[Angola]] during [[Angolan Civil War|the civil war]].<ref name="dates">Meisler, Stanley. ''United Nations: The First Fifty Years'', 1997. Page 368.</ref> It was established by [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 626]] on December 20, 1988.
In the civil war, the Soviet Union and Cuba backed the Movimento Popular de Libertação de Angola (MPLA), while South Africa and the United States backed the União Nacional para a Independência Total de Angola (UNITA). The MPLA became the stronger party.<ref name="un-bg">[https://www.un.org/Depts/DPKO/Missions/unavem1/UnavemIB.htm UNAVEM I: Background]</ref>
UNAVEM I's purpose was oversee withdrawal of the Cuban troops.<ref name="un-bg"/> This mission was a success.<ref>[https://www.un.org/Depts/DPKO/Missions/unavem1/UnavemIM.htm UNAVEM I: Mandate]</ref>
The [[United Nations]] created a follow up mission, [[United Nations Angola Verification Mission II]], in 1991.<ref name="dates"/>
==See also== * [[Cuban intervention in Angola]] * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Janos_Besenyo/publication/320876006_A_participacao_da_Hungria_nas_missoes_de_paz_da_ONU_em_Angola/links/5a005df24585159634b76024/A-participacao-da-Hungria-nas-missoes-de-paz-da-ONU-em-Angola.pdf O contexto das missões UNAVEM/MONUA], in: A participação da Hungria nas missões de paz da ONU em Angola * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Janos_Besenyo/publication/320876006_A_participacao_da_Hungria_nas_missoes_de_paz_da_ONU_em_Angola/links/5a005df24585159634b76024/A-participacao-da-Hungria-nas-missoes-de-paz-da-ONU-em-Angola.pdf Experiências dos operacionais húngaros em Angola depoimentos], in: A participação da Hungria nas missões de paz da ONU em Angola.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{UN-stub}} [[Category:Angolan Civil War]] [[Category:United Nations operations in Angola]] [[Category:History of Angola]] [[Category:1989 in Africa]] [[Category:1990s in Africa]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1989]] [[Category:1991 disestablishments]] {{Angola-stub}}

page.title: University of Zimbabwe Lake Kariba Research Station

revision.text:
The '''University of Zimbabwe Lake Kariba Research Station''' is a [[research station]] in the Nyamhunga suburb of [[Kariba, Zimbabwe|Kariba]].<ref>{{cite map|publisher=Surveyor General, Zimbabwe|title=1:250,0000 Series: Kariba|cartography=|edition=1998|section=}}</ref> It is operated by the [[University of Zimbabwe]]. Station staff have published research on topics such as fish diets <ref>{{cite journal|last=Sanyanga|first=R.A.|authorlink=|title=Food composition and selectivity of ''Synodontis zambezensis'' (Pisces: Mochokidae) in Lake Kariba, and the ecological implications |journal=Hydrobiologia|volume=361|issue=|pages=89–99|publisher=Springer-Verlag|location=Berlin|year=2004|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/k3854505u786p463/|format=[[abstract (summary)|abstract]]|issn=|doi=10.1023/A:1003101813361|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref> and population dynamics <ref>{{cite journal|last=Hustler|first=K.|authorlink=|author2=Marshall, B.E. |title=Population dynamics of two small cichlid fish species in a tropical man-made lake (Lake Kariba)|journal=[[Hydrobiologia]]|volume=190|issue=|pages=253–262|publisher=Springer-Verlag|location=Berlin|year=1990|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/q361u118rxk47gp8/|format=[[abstract (summary)|abstract]]|issn=|doi=10.1007/BF00008193|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref> and climate change.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Magadza|first=C.H.D.|authorlink=|title=Climate Change Impacts and Human Settlements in Africa: Prospects for Adaptation|journal=Environmental Monitoring and Assessment|volume=61|issue=|pages=193–205|publisher=Springer-Verlag|location=Berlin|year=2000|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/pl7r774n52l87610/|format=[[abstract (summary)|abstract]]|issn=|doi=10.1023/A:1006355210516|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Research stations]] [[Category:Research institutes in Africa]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:University of Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mashonaland West Province]]
{{Zimbabwe-org-stub}}
